unnormalised: ## My Misadventures with PNRs and More: A Travel Identifier Comedy
normalised: My Misadventures with P-N-Rs and More: A Travel Identifier Comedy

unnormalised: Alright folks, buckle up, because I'm about to tell you a tale of travel woe, all thanks to the glorious world of identifiers. You know, those cryptic codes that airlines and railways love to throw around, making you feel like you're deciphering ancient hieroglyphics? Yeah, those.
normalised: Alright folks, buckle up, because I'm about to tell you a tale of travel woe, all thanks to the glorious world of identifiers. You know, those cryptic codes that airlines and railways love to throw around, making you feel like you're deciphering ancient hieroglyphics? Yeah, those.

unnormalised: It all started with a "spontaneous" trip to Goa. I say "spontaneous" because it involved me frantically refreshing the IRCTC website for three days straight, trying to snag a confirmed ticket. Finally, victory! Except, the only berth I could get was RAC, which, for the uninitiated, stands for "Reservation Against Cancellation." Sounds promising, right? Wrong. It basically means you're half-pregnant with a seat. You might get one, you might not. Your PNR, a glorious string of digits, is your only hope.

unnormalised: My PNR, bless its little numerical heart, became my obsession. I checked it every five minutes. I dreamt of it. I even tried to bribe the TTE (Travelling Ticket Examiner) with a samosa. (He politely declined, but I appreciated the effort.) The PNR was my travel mantra.

unnormalised: Then there's the flight bookings. Oh, the joys of airlines and their complicated reservation systems! I booked a round-trip ticket to Goa with IndiGo, and suddenly my email inbox became a landfill of confirmation emails, booking references, and itinerary updates. Each email proudly displayed my PNR (or sometimes, the airline’s version of it, which seemed to be a completely different code, just to mess with me).

unnormalised: I also had the unfortunate event of booking through a shady online travel agent (OTA). Lesson learned: Stick to the official sites, kids! These companies are the real deal, even if their user interfaces look like a website from the early 2000s. They asked for my passport details (Passport No. X1234567, just kidding... mostly!), Aadhar card no. (Don't even think about it!), my mother's maiden name, and my blood type. I started to suspect they were actually building a profile for some top-secret government agency.

unnormalised: So, here I am, a seasoned traveller reduced to a gibbering mess by the tyranny of travel identifiers. From elusive PNRs to mythical booking IDs, these codes have become the bane of my existence, a constant reminder that travel, while glorious, is also a logistical nightmare. Next time I will just take the bus, the seat no. will be mine and only mine, nobody can steal it!
